title: Friday, 16th November 2018

annotations.prefLabel: Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC

Hello. Back again. Markets Live. FTAlpha's thing with the thing.

lillo hello

Given the fluidity of the political situation and the lack of precedents or institutional guidelines which would allow to infer the course of events, it is not very useful to try and guess precisely what may happen now.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Any number of scenarios previously deemed impossible are now entirely plausible. What we can do however is to outline a few constant observations that can help frame our clients' views on future events and eventual outcomes.
 The main take-away from the past few days is that the current government does not have unity or legitimacy sufficient to drive an orderly Brexit process. Similarly, other plausible governments, be it a new leader, or a new party, do not offer a realistic prospect of a better defined, coherent position.
 The implication is that in any event, uncertainty over the operating environment of any firm and any investor in the UK will remain dangerously high for likely months to come. This is not just as both the Labour and Conservative Parties struggle to grapple with the large, specific, questions Brexit poses, but also as these questions drive broader dysfunction within both parties. This does not bode well for investment (we recall in this context that the UK's current account deficit makes it dependent on foreign funding and in particular on foreign direct investment) or for near-term growth.

Dec69 - Skeptic as a thought process, what's the outlook, with Apple suppliers suffering, NVidia/AMD in the crapper, has the cycle finally turned, as consumerism consumes itself?

BE11:18am

For the current situation to deteriorate sharply, we believe equity market nervousness would need to spread to funding markets. Thus far there appears no evidence of this: short-term GBP funding showed limited strain, as 3m GBP LIBOR remains stable, ~10 bp above 3m GBP OIS vs the Feb-12 peak of 60 bp and 25bp post Brexit vote. Similarly, US$/GBP xccy basis swap is flat vs a 20bp increase post Brexit vote.

Excel Developer @BE: more the case that Banks are amplified bets on the macroeconomy, hence Brexit bad, economy bad, RBS bad.
cheeckychappy @Dec69 - Skeptic I wouldn't be too concerned there are some barbers who are rather well informed (wink wink).
BE11:18am

Even in the event where the (currently stable) situation in bank funding markets deteriorates sharply, we note that today: (1) banks are stronger; (2) the “crisis backstops” – put in place to deal with the 2008/9 financial crisis and the € sovereign crisis – remain in place, and finally (3) at
extremis, the Bank of England could choose to offer
additional liquidity (as following the Brexit vote), based on banks’ sizeable pools of collateral pre-cleared with the BoE. Combined, the overall picture is reassuring, in our view.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Our economists argue that the political reaction to
the Withdrawal Agreement has increased the risk of a
disorderly Brexit. The next key hurdle is the ratification of the Withdrawal agreement by the House of Commons. If voted down, our economists believe this could lead to (i) a subsequent attempt to pass an amended Withdrawal
agreement, (ii) a second referendum, or (iii) a “no deal” cliff edge departure. For UK exposed banks, we view this as a clearly incremental negative, as it can affect the outlook through volumes, margins and credit losses. Our
Conviction List is positioned for this - our sole “UK bank”
on the CL is STAN (Buy), alongside 4 eurozone banks. We are Sell rated on Lloyds.

red @Excel Developerbuying the banks becomes easier on no deal brexit. you get the capitulation then can move in.

We look at what was the perceived network risk of possible air transport disruption in the event of a ‘Hard Brexit’ as they stood at the time of the Leave vote at the end of June 2016 and what these are now. We conclude that exposure of the major airlines has fallen over this time from 25% of the network to 19% given AOC approvals and progress on the UK/US bilateral discussions.

11:20 am
BE11:21am

However, UK/EU point-to-point exposure still significant
Despite some mitigation, 19% of networks remain exposed to UK-EU point-to-point routes, with easyJet the most exposed at 42% (was 65%). Ryanair’s exposure is 33%, IAG’s 27% and Wizz’s is 23%. AF-KLMs and LHA AG’s exposures are both around 6%.

Excel Developer net stable funding ratios https://www.bis.org/bcbs/publ/d295.pdf

red the prob with taking no deal off the table means may has no stick with which to go back to the eu. so its hard to see what see can offer on a second vote if the first fails. the only variable is the strength of MP's bowels, scared of voting themselves into no deal.
Flaneur Surprised non-south coast based shipping outfits and port operators arent getting a rise of this...
Excel Developer @red: sure. @be: there are now stable funding ratio thingummy jigs in place to prevent funding becoming an issue. see Basle III link above (once it comes out of pending.)

With that said, the European Commission intends to avoid disruption However, possible missed in yesterday’s headlines, the EC published a paper on Wednesday entitled ‘Preparing for the withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the European Union: a Contingency Action Plan.’ This laid out a number of measures that should ensure uninterrupted flights even in the event of a ‘No Deal’ scenario.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

In this context, easyjet looks the most exposed. Taking its sensitivity analysis from its last Report & Accounts and applying it to yesterday’s fall in Sterling suggests a FX headwind of ~£23m at the PAT level. This is equivalent to a 5% reduction vs. FY19 PAT consensus of £461m, making yesterday’s 6.6% share price fall the most rational in the sector.

Tom Dalgleish @DEC69 where do you get that stuff?
BE11:23am

Conversely, we think the Wizz’s 5% fall yesterday looks the least rational. In part this reflects the fact that the move in Sterling equates to a 1.9% FX headwind vs FY20 consensus PAT of €367m. Additionally, being London listed but Euro reporting, normally a fall in Sterling vs its US$ assets and Euro income streams should result in a positive impact on the stock price. This was not seen yesterday.

Cat in a box @red threatening no-deal was always the Blazing Saddles approach to negotiation anyway

The fruits of the new UK housing market recovery since 2013 have buttressed the sector’s balance sheets to net cash positions almost across the board. This enables the high free cash flow generation we forecast in 2019-2022 to be paid out in dividends (we include in our assumptions the current level of special payments). These dividend forecasts through to 2022 comprise an attractive and sustained +7% average yield for the 10 stocks at 55-65% average FCF payout ratio. This includes 8-12% dividend yields in the same period for the 3 national volume builders (Persimmon, Barratt and Taylor Wimpey) at 80-90% FCF payout ratios.

Dec69 - Skeptic Were HSBC drinking prior to typing 30% fall, wasn't the "leaver" vote a 25% fall? stopped clock analysis?
red think about foreign buyers seeing a 30% drop plus another 20% on the exchange rate
BE11:30am

We expect sector EBIT to fall on average by 33% in FY2018-20 and recover on average by 23% in the following two years to 2022. More importantly, we forecast aggregate free cash flow to grow 13% in 2019 as we expect land investment to fall and free cash flow to remain higher in 2021-22e than 2018 as absolute levels of land investment are at lower values per plot in the south. We then forecast aggregate free cash flow to slip in 2021-22 back to the 2018e level as land investment on average increases to house completions levels.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

AstraZeneca announced today the overall survival (OS) results of the Phase III
MYSTIC trial evaluating Imfinzi monotherapy or combination with tremelimumab versus standard of care (SoC) chemotherapy in first-line epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) and anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) wild-type, locally-advanced or metastatic (stage IV) non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). The study failed to meet the primary endpoint of improving OS with Imfinzi compared to SoC chemotherapy.
This negative OS readout follows a negative progression free survival (PFS) readout announced in 2017. Given both the headline negative read outs and in context of positive data sets for other PD(L)1 agents in this setting (most notably for Merck’s Keytruda) it is unclear to us what role Imfinzi may play (if any) in the frontline NSCLC market even as a monotherapy.
We do not include any sales for Imfinzi in the front-line NSCLC setting following failure to meet the PFS endpoint last year and view this failure as a further sentiment negative. We are below consensus on our Imfinzi estimates, and forecast 2023E Imfinzi sales of $2.4 bn (9% of group sales).

BE11:39am

Our model includes nothing for MYSTIC, reflecting 0% chance of success and, hence, today’s result
implies no downside to our forecasts.
Consensus doesn’t break out Imfinzi forecasts by indication, but we note that consensus has 2023
forecasts for the Imfinzi/treme combo across all indications (broader than lung) of $650m, equating to
2.4% of 2023 Revenues. This company consensus forecast will also include something for combo use in Head &
Neck cancer (data late this year), Bladder cancer (data next year) and Liver cancer (data 2020), and only around
half of analysts currently include anything for the combo approach in models. Removing 2023 sales of $250m
from models at 50% EBITDA would equate to a c1.2% hit to 2023 Core EPS.
MYSTIC OS failure removes a bear-point, allowing investors to focus on the positives for 2019, i.e. 1)
New launch upside (we see Tagrisso, Imfinzi and Fasenra launches beating), 2) Return to EPS growth in
2019, where we see the company growing Core EPS double digit, and 3) Further pipeline optionality, i.e.
roxadustat Phase III data in H1’19, Calquence Phase III data in H2’19, Lynparza Prostate cancer data in H2’19.

Pharma @wayneJ - agree that a bad brexit will keep the Tories out for a generation, although I suspect we disagree on the meaning of "bad" in this context.I think May's deal will kill any chances of the Conservatives forming a government until all their current MPs have retired. Perhaps longer.

Looking to 2019, we see Astra continuing to offer the
strongest near- and medium-term growth outlook in the sector, and we see room for a further re-rating as the company delivers on the long-awaited return to EPS growth in 2019 and beyond, driven by new launch uptake, further pipeline success and underlying margin expansion.

MYSTIC OS was one of two key news flow catalysts remaining for this year – we still await top-line cardiovascular safety data for HIF-PHi roxadustat.

BE11:59am

We now explicitly model BAT's US Menthol volumes falling ~50% 2023-25. We cut our EPS estimates 4-11% 2023-25 and our PT from 3920p to 2750p. As we set out in our report on Monday this week here, our analysis suggests that BAT's US menthol portfolio accounts for ~60% of their US cigarette profits and ~25% of overall group profits in 2018. Newport is BAT's biggest brand in the US (c.48% US revenues) and the No. 1 menthol brand in the US with ~54% market share.

BE11:59am

BAT has fallen 20% inside 5 trading days, with the stock now on ~9x forward earnings. However, with BAT's net debt to EBITDA at 4x, its EM FX exposure at 40% of sales and its payout ratio at 65%, we continue to tread cautiously. Additionally, we note BAT's net debt to market cap is now at 72% (~£46bn of debt on a market cap of £64bn). Whilst this isn't a commonly used ratio, it is noteworthy when you are faced with potential challenges to the core US business.

We assume a 2% to 12% EBIT downside risk on BATS and 1% on IMB, depending on the % of current menthol smokers switching to non-menthol cigarettes and the menthol consumers’ loyalty to its menthol brands. Overall, we assume a 90% switch (10pp loss to NGP menthol products) and consumers loyalty to the brand given all of BATS’ menthol brands have non-menthol versions which would help mitigate any decline in usage. Note that at the time of the 2013 “menthol fears”, Lorillard derated by 10% vs. US tobacco.

The agency gives manufacturers the opportunity to curtail by themselves the youth nicotine uptick as it concedes that a ban of ENDS would deny the opportunities for current smokers to switch from combustible. Yet in the absence of
results, the FDA has the power to eliminate any application enforcement discretion to any currently marketed
ENDS product (i.e. products would have to come off the market pending FDA authorization through the
PMTA pathway). By and large, the main manufacturers have already announced actions to limit youth access
or curtail flavor offerings.
